content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												How did this game survive when City of Heroes died out?I have played through the game three times now and completed the story as a Tech, Meta, and Magic character. But once you hit level 30 and complete the main story, there is nothing left to do except PVP, which unless you're shilling out the dollars (or whatever currency your country runs on), you're pretty much guaranteed to lose.The power selection is also EXTREMELY limited compared to other super hero games like City of Heroes, or Champions Online. Each power set is divided up into two types which as far as I can tell boil down to DPS vs Crowd Control.Their website hasn't been updated since War of the Light, so I'm going to tell you which power sets are available in the game as of the time of writing this. The Power Sets for those who aren't paying a subscription are Fire, Ice, Gadgets, Mental, Nature, and Sorcery.The powers sets for those who do pay a subscription includes the previons ones, as well as Light (green / yellow rings), Rage (red ring), Earth, Lightning, Quantum (time / space),  Blessed / Cursed (good and evil magic), and Munitions (lots of guns).They also plan to include additional paid for powers such as Water and Serums.Unfortunately these new power sets contribute nothing to the game's replay value. The story is the same regardless, and once again, there's nothing to do except PVP once you complete it.The game has also begun to die out. When I first starting playing the game, the streets were filled with heroes and villains. When I tried to do a PVP server, I could scarcely go on a mission without being dog piled by the enemy team. Now the game is mostly deserted on both PVP and PVE servers. I think I found maybe 2 or 3 enemies that were still hunting players on PVP servers, but that's it.The only travel powers that are any fun is Speed Force and Acrobatics. Flight and the hover discs are a joke, nobody seems to like them. Probably because at a certain level, you can get a jet booster with Acrobatics that allows you to get around just as easily as flight, and in a much faster method. That's right, FLIGHT is the slowest travel power in the game!The game also lacks a character diversity concept such as races. I get that the story is that you were a human that inherited super powers, but they could have at least included a racial template such as Thanagarian, Kryptonian, Martian, Atlantean, Cyborg, Robot, and so on. You can get skins for some of these races, and you can get similar powers, but these are purely cosmetic and don't affect your strengths and weaknesses at all.DC Universe Online is a super hero game that falls short when compared to many other games of its genre. It is not worth the money they want you to pump into it, and is already dying as it is. The game should be allowed to go out with whatever dignity it has left, rather than trying to resuscitate it.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												For those out of the loop, this probably represents the last of the big old-style MMOs. Even though it was only released in 2011, there’s something about it that feels more tired than Bruce Wayne’s put upon butler. Indeed, there’s a grind to almost every mission, the graphics don’t exactly sparkle (even on new hardware), and how you choose to fight seems to have very little bearing on the outcome of battle. Speedy level progression and focus on all combat, all the time might prove tedious if you're someone who enjoys exploring new worlds for the thrill of mystery and discovery. The largely instanced, repeatable endgame content is fun, but it's not inviting enough to make it worth paying a monthly fee for it. But even if it doesn't provide enough new content to sustain you beyond a couple of weeks, DC Universe Online is generally entertaining, and comic book fans will be happy that the license was handled with care.Perhaps the best gameplay feature of DCUO is the design of its default UI layout and keybinds. Instead of the standard MMOG mechanic of "tab-target, auto-attack, fire-all-your-cooldowns-and-wait-for-refresh" that leaves you a slave to whack-a-mole style hotbuttons and timers, DCUO maps the entirety of your primary weapon set to a single button. Through a series of "clicks" and "holds," your avatar will execute different combinations of superpowered techniques that are the bread and butter of your life as a hero or villain. The additional powers you can use are yours to command at YOUR discretion, not the whim of a global cooldown, and you may find yourself going as long as an hour or two without needing to activate a single one. This combination of simplicity and freedom allow you to do something that has become less common in MMOGs - you can actually watch the action unfold instead of always having your eyes fixed to your hotbars. This also has allowed the DCUO devs to include clever boss fight mechanics that include a reliance on environmental awareness, since it's easier to see what's going on around you.

Which I could *sort of* forgive if the gameplay allowed for excitement or even empowerement in a game that has you play as a superhero. Instead, all you get is a bland MMO with countless deus ex machina moments, limited options and frankly clunky UI and controls. Though it technically is playable without shelling out cash, it REALLY wants you to and it's not afraid to show it. The irksome thing is, even if you do, it remains, at its core, bland.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Jogo simplesmente sensacional! O que posso dizer de um jogo como este, onde eu posso criar o meu próprio Super-Herói ou me inspirar nos que eu assistia e lia quando criança? Poxa, encontrei esse jogo tarde de mais eu acho, gostaria de ter o conhecido mais cedo, porque cara, que joguinho pra viciar. Os gráficos para um MMO são lindos, e os poderes que se pode ter também. As quests são em geral fáceis, mas as dungeons são muito ♥♥♥♥! Proporcionando ao jogador uma dificuldade razoável, onde várias vezes você vai morrer, até você achar o ponto fraco do inimigo e bater lá. O jogo tem um sistema de cash e premium member, ou Legendary, mas não muda em nada o gameplay, só da ao jogador vantagens de ter TODAS as DLCs do jogo de graça e a opção de criar uma Liga, e o preço do membro mensal não chega a ser tão caro, R$23,99, sendo que nos EUA são U$14,99, ou seja, estamos saindo com lucro, pois a mensalidade seria quase R$60,00. Mas enfim, não estou dizendo para você pagar mensalmente, você pode simplesmente comprar as DLCs e viver sua vida.   A busca pelo level 30 é complicada, demora bastante para você upar, tendo que fazer duas ou até mesmo 3 missões para upar metade do level, mas é assim mesmo, se você quer facilidade vai jogar Minecraft.    Enfim pessoal, jogo 100% recomendado, se você gosta do universo DC, você vai amar esse jogo, os gráficos são lindos, a jogabilidade quase que perfeita, a história é boa, e a dublagem em inglês sensacional.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												How did this game survive when City of Heroes died out?I have played through the game three times now and completed the story as a Tech, Meta, and Magic character. But once you hit level 30 and complete the main story, there is nothing left to do except PVP, which unless you're shilling out the dollars (or whatever currency your country runs on), you're pretty much guaranteed to lose.The power selection is also EXTREMELY limited compared to other super hero games like City of Heroes, or Champions Online. Each power set is divided up into two types which as far as I can tell boil down to DPS vs Crowd Control.Their website hasn't been updated since War of the Light, so I'm going to tell you which power sets are available in the game as of the time of writing this. The Power Sets for those who aren't paying a subscription are Fire, Ice, Gadgets, Mental, Nature, and Sorcery.The powers sets for those who do pay a subscription includes the previons ones, as well as Light (green / yellow rings), Rage (red ring), Earth, Lightning, Quantum (time / space),  Blessed / Cursed (good and evil magic), and Munitions (lots of guns).They also plan to include additional paid for powers such as Water and Serums.Unfortunately these new power sets contribute nothing to the game's replay value. The story is the same regardless, and once again, there's nothing to do except PVP once you complete it.The game has also begun to die out. When I first starting playing the game, the streets were filled with heroes and villains. When I tried to do a PVP server, I could scarcely go on a mission without being dog piled by the enemy team. Now the game is mostly deserted on both PVP and PVE servers. I think I found maybe 2 or 3 enemies that were still hunting players on PVP servers, but that's it.The only travel powers that are any fun is Speed Force and Acrobatics. Flight and the hover discs are a joke, nobody seems to like them. Probably because at a certain level, you can get a jet booster with Acrobatics that allows you to get around just as easily as flight, and in a much faster method. That's right, FLIGHT is the slowest travel power in the game!The game also lacks a character diversity concept such as races. I get that the story is that you were a human that inherited super powers, but they could have at least included a racial template such as Thanagarian, Kryptonian, Martian, Atlantean, Cyborg, Robot, and so on. You can get skins for some of these races, and you can get similar powers, but these are purely cosmetic and don't affect your strengths and weaknesses at all.DC Universe Online is a super hero game that falls short when compared to many other games of its genre. It is not worth the money they want you to pump into it, and is already dying as it is. The game should be allowed to go out with whatever dignity it has left, rather than trying to resuscitate it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Time for a good, bad, and ugly review. (NON PVP player) Final verdict at the end. ****************  The Good things *********************Character generation – IMHO more MMO's should adopt this style of both character creation, and customization.  Your stats and abilities are almost totally independent of your characters appearance, and there are a LOT of appearance options to customize your hero.  I personally Cosplay my DC character as Starlord from the Guardians of the Galaxy movie, and it looks and feels awesome to play!Action/fighting/button mashing combat – If you are like me, you are sick of the action/hotbar style mmo mechanic.  This game has a more traditional action game approach to controls, and works BEST with a controller, but also well with a mouse and keyboard. If you like Games that give you button combos, active dodging and countering, you will like this.  Story – It is clearly a “theme park” mmo in every sense of the word.  IMHO it does this well, each story arc is mostly fun, and only a handful felt boring or like something I couldn't wait to finish.  Nothing too deep, nothing too shallow. Nice bite sized plots that you can finish in a few hours at a time. Great for casual gaming. Gotham – The city of Gotham is legit, and makes you feel like you are in the Batman animated series in many ways. Sound and graphics – for an MMO, these look great with everything maxed out.  The colors, the characters, and the environments (especially gotham) are full of eye candy.  Gameplay overall – The game play is very addictive as I mentioned before, even just flying/running/climbing around the cities is fun. The fighting action is great. But another great thing are the movement modes, I find acrobatics/grapplinghook to be the most fun to play, and flight to be the most useful. Free to play – This is kind of both a good and bad – the free to play model being used here is what I prefer to call – the Extended preview model.  The free elements are enough to level you to 30 and beyond, but you will be limited in a lot of ways, and won't get to experiment with all the possible power and weapon combos.  As free to play games go, if you enjoy the game you will be getting a LOT out of the game even if you never buy anything. ********************* The bad things ************************Grind - The level range is only 1-30, and when it finishes, the game devolves into repeating content for marks which you use to buy gear that raises your level (similar to destiny's light level).  This is fun for a little while, but once you see how long it takes to grind for marks, and how much content you have to repeat to do it... you will likely quit, most people I know get their full Tier 1, then either quit, or make a new toon experience another storyline up to thirty, then quit. Lots of empty space – I can't tell you how often I'm traveling around, especially in Metropolis, and feel like the city is empty and unfinished.  Huge sections of the map have almost no reason for going there, except exploring for collectible elements.  No random enemies to fight, no quests... I'd say only about 1/3 of the map for each city has actual content in it, the rest is just travel and exploration fodder. The hideout system – This is boring to me, it's got a lot going for it I suppose if you like these things, but I just can't get into the layouts or designs.  However, unlike most other MMO's where a home is just a fun vanity collectible box, you NEED a hideout or else you won't get certain upgrades, buff and perks... My hideout is basically an empty warehouse looking place with a few key elements so I can get my buffs...Low level instances – The balance on the low level 4 player instances can be frustrating.  They can be very difficult to beat at the level they claim to be designed for, and often a high level player will be in it, which seems to make it harder for everyone else.  It's not really free to play – This depends on your perspective, for me, I don't expect games to be totally free... either I need to buy it, or buy things in microtransactions, or pay for monthly. Nothing is free. I like FTP that lets me try a game like this before committing to it with a monthly sub.  The problem is, when I subbed, I had no idea what endgame was like, or that I'd basically be grinding for gear... **************** The Ugly things – Not too many ugly things here... *******************The Grind – Yes, I mentioned it before, but it really gets annoying past 30.  Even though more and more content opens up as you increase your level tier... All it really amounts to, is new instances to grind for marks.  There are no new levels, no new story arcs (not really).  If DCUO had proper content expansions for post 30, something to give you a REAL reason to level up (new story arcs, new levels etc), it would really be something special and give you a reason to grind. No cross platform between PC and PS4, but you CAN play PS4 with PS3. - This sucks for people like me who are master race PC users, but whose friends and family are all Console limited.  My Son and Wife both wanted to play with me, but can't... but at least they can play together... without me! :(********************* Final Verdict *********************Totally worth playing till 30, and a little beyond. Totally worth a short sub to unlock all the powers etc, or buy them outright one by one to save some money. I subbed for 3 months, and will cancel before it renews. I got my fun out of it, and will sub again only if any major additions or changes warrant it.

content:
Posted: February 7
												For the record, if this wasn't free to play, or if Champions Online was (for real, though, it's not really free), I wouldn't recommend it. Just saying.DC Universe Online is one of the best superhero MMOs. It's better than anything Marvel has done in the MMO field. It's at least on par with Champions Online (I don't like CO, but some do, and I've not played it much). I'd even say it's one of the better superhero games ever made. Even so, it's still only mediocre.Don't mistake me. The first few hours are fun, and just running/climbing/flying through the city is a lot of fun. The character customization options are limited, but passable. The abilty trees are interesting, but you're gonna want to pick a path you like pretty early on, or risk getting stuck at the difficulty curve right about level 16 and being stuck with your current abilities for a while until you finally get leveling again.That difficulty curve around levels 15-19 is obnoxious, and convinced me to stop plpaying. If I have put in more money than $10 for a DLC pack, I would have been more committed, but since it was largely a free experience, there was no investment to redeem. Again, the game being free made it worth it, and the ability to play the entire game, unrestricted, free of charge makes this far more worth your time and money than Champions Online in my book.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												It's sad, the potential it had, ruined by microtransactions and random DLC. It's like what another user said in the game, the developers serve you a cookie crumb and it's the best cookie crumb you had. They offer you another crumb from their cookie and price it something like $15, and that's when you pay it only to find out it tasted the same as the regular cookie crumb you got. I fully agree with that, and it's not the end of the trail of cookie crumbs, ooooh no, my friend. It's just the beginning of a long-line of microtransactions just so you can feast on the rest of the cookie crumbs. It's even worse when you look outside of the DLC and into the other microtransactions. WHAT!? I NEED TO FORK OVER MORE CASH JUST TO GET TO CONTINUE PLAYING THE GAME!? When I first saw this, I felt like growing my hair long enough to make a noose from it as it's still attached to my head. Wait, MORE MICROTRANSACTIONS!? I feel like it's rather a freely-microtransactionable-playable game than a free-to-play game. Nevermind the amazing gameplays that are possible, microtransactions bring the buzzkill. All I ask about this game for it to be approved is simple; loosen up on the DLC and remove most microtransactions so we can feel like it's an actual free game. Maybe then I'll return to the game. Before I end this rant, let me tell you...I don't care if you like the game (if you do, good for you) or if you hate the game, all I care is to warn you to not waste your money on this game's wasteful time of DLC and fun (economically and literally) absorber of microtransactions. Spending your money on a wishlisted game instead is something to do better than falling into the microtransactions like a internet using idiot falling easily to viruses. I hope you enjoy your day if you took the time to read it all.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												I've played this game for years on ps3 and ps4 and recently decided to start playing again. To be honest, while it isn't a bad game it can feel grindy like any MMO, so i strongly suggest playing this game with friends or else your experience might suck due to the fact that Matchmaking isn't skill based, and friends usually make most things enjoyable.TLDR; Good game, great customization options, grindy as hell like any MMO, Don't buy DLC but do legendery if you can afford it, and the game really doesn't start until level 30, and find friends Pros.Combat is fun, you use your weapon combos mostly BUT, you focus on your powers if you know how to manage a mana bar-Lots of customizable options, make your hero/villain look as badass or as goofy as you want   -While you can't play as your favorite iconics  in the open world, you can make them look close, or    better-Easy to get into -Story is well written and voice acting is on point.-Seasonal events, Instances and raids to keep you busy-You can play as your favorite heroes and villains** but only in a few "Instances" and pvpCons.-On top of grinding missions, you have to grind for skill points too which you use for your weapon combos and passive stat upgrades  - On top of this, if you're in the higher level raids and instances, it's pretty much expected for you to have a good number of skill points which can lead to being kicked. This can be avoided if you get a good League (guild) or just play with friends-Paying can be annoying as hell if you haven't played MMOs like WoW, even then the free to play aspect of this game sucks except as an introductory stage since the game doesn't really start untill level 30 .    -It's around 15$ usd a month for Legendary which gives you access to all DLC, your money isn't limited (the most you can have with a free to play is 1,500. For comparison, there are items in the marketplace that go for millions of in game cash), more inventory and bank spaces- In my opinion,  do not buy the dlcs for this game  Getting the DLC only gives you access to that specific content and Premium membership, while legendary gives you what I stated before as well as a certain in game currency the game gives you every month, that you can use for cosmetics and such.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												The Good: Fun. That word is thrown around alot in this industry and to be honest this game deserves it. Grinding doesn't feel like it drags on, PVP is exciting and engaging. The game rewards players for being social. It has great graphics, sound, and story, the voice acting engages players in a way that no MMO has before.The Bad: It's difficult finding tight groups you can run with where everyone has a job and they know what they have to do. healers forget to heal, tanks don't tank, controllers think using damage role generates energy, and damage role guys are there to pick up  Investigations.Other thoughts: Why do so many people badmouth this game over lost accounts? I've seen about 20 negative reviews from people who'd rather whaaa about "losing all their DLC" rather than contacting Daybreak about getting their account back. Whiny maggots.

content:
Posted: January 8
												Here's a little background to justify my statements. I started playing this game shortly after release as a FREE player. DCUO at that point was fairly balanced and didn't show much of a P2W advantage for being a premium member and paying for the sub, but there were some advantages. Having a limited amount of usable credits on hand wasn't a big deal if you knew how to manage your spending and income you could side step the escrow emplaced on the F2P players. I later paid for the premium and maintained it for about 3 months, allowing me to make new characters with the new powers they released in the expansions (when I cancelled my sub, I lost access to the expansions, but was able to maintain the characters made from them) which was the main reason for me getting the premuim for that duration.This game is fun, the play style is exciting and is enhanced moreso when playing with a friend. The outfit choices are pleasing and the higher tier gear has those iconic looks that everyone should crave.This game has a low level cap mainly because it's designed for end game PVP, the PVP is unbalanced and broken, good luck finding anyone to go up against in the 8 vs 8 arena. They added a cool down to the que and made it cost real money to run more than once a day on pretty much all instances and arenas (which are the end game things to do). Basically after hitting 30 and having done all your main story line mission, you'll get bored real quick and decide to play something that has more to offer.I suggest finding a different game until the devs make some major changes to this game.

When I first saw this, I felt like growing my hair long enough to make a noose from it as it's still attached to my head. Wait, MORE MICROTRANSACTIONS!? I feel like it's rather a freely-microtransactionable-playable game than a free-to-play game. Nevermind the amazing gameplays that are possible, microtransactions bring the buzzkill. All I ask about this game for it to be approved is simple; loosen up on the DLC and remove most microtransactions so we can feel like it's an actual free game. Maybe then I'll return to the game. Before I end this rant, let me tell you...I don't care if you like the game (if you do, good for you) or if you hate the game, all I care is to warn you to not waste your money on this game's wasteful time of DLC and fun (economically and literally) absorber of microtransactions. Spending your money on a wishlisted game instead is something to do better than falling into the microtransactions like a internet using idiot falling easily to viruses. I hope you enjoy your day if you took the time to read it all.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												Here's a little background to justify my statements. I started playing this game shortly after release as a FREE player. DCUO at that point was fairly balanced and didn't show much of a P2W advantage for being a premium member and paying for the sub, but there were some advantages. Having a limited amount of usable credits on hand wasn't a big deal if you knew how to manage your spending and income you could side step the escrow emplaced on the F2P players. I later paid for the premium and maintained it for about 3 months, allowing me to make new characters with the new powers they released in the expansions (when I cancelled my sub, I lost access to the expansions, but was able to maintain the characters made from them) which was the main reason for me getting the premuim for that duration.This game is fun, the play style is exciting and is enhanced moreso when playing with a friend. The outfit choices are pleasing and the higher tier gear has those iconic looks that everyone should crave.This game has a low level cap mainly because it's designed for end game PVP, the PVP is unbalanced and broken, good luck finding anyone to go up against in the 8 vs 8 arena. They added a cool down to the que and made it cost real money to run more than once a day on pretty much all instances and arenas (which are the end game things to do). Basically after hitting 30 and having done all your main story line mission, you'll get bored real quick and decide to play something that has more to offer.I suggest finding a different game until the devs make some major changes to this game.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												I believe this is a highly underrated game. While I haven't played in years, I know you can not pay a dime, while not being able to play any endgame, there is much fun to be had.For me, I mostly enjoyed my knowledge of heroes and villains in the DC universe increasing 100 fold.  From the big ones to the small, there are so many encounters, either talking or fighting to be had.It's beat to approach this not as mmo, but an rpg.  Bring a friend or 3 and do the many 4 man instances or 2 man ones.  Even alone groups can be found and there is much lore to dive into.You get many customization options from powers to weapons.  So any power can be combined with any weapons giving you so many choices of specs. While your power stays the same, weapons can be changed very often.The minimal abilities is great as well. Most mmos give you 2 to 3 dozen buttons to push, where you have about 7 here.If you're a super hero, comic, or DC fan you have nothing to lose by checking out this free game.If you're looking for an mmo to dive into hardcore, you need to spend money and you're probably better off playing a newer mmo.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												DC Universe is one of the best games I ever played. I got addicted to it real quick. It's easy to learn but hard to master. Progression is 1-30 then T1-T6. 1-30 takes you a day and I mean an ENTIRE day if you spend the WHOLE day grinding non-stop. If you're a working man who only has a couple of hours each day, it'll take you a week. With a party it's a lot faster. You have to join a league or else you'll get nowhere in this game. Please don't PUG too much. Plan instances with your league. You'll get♥♥♥♥♥♥done much faster that way. You have to get membership after level 30 because you won't be able to progress without it as you lack all the DLC's. And last thing, if you only have two hours a day to play this game, then this game is not for you. I'm saying that because you wouldn't be getting the full experience, only a sample. Yes, it's P2W but it's worth it. I highly recommend this game.

												DCUO is a great game. It is pretty recomended that you join a league to help get some farm in some raids. Speaking of said raids it is better if you get a membership either by getting one of their membership cards or buying one because trying to do raids as a free to play will not work very well until after you reach t3. There are times where you'll get frustraited during the game, don't worry just take out your anger by blaming daybreak. Lots of bugs and stuff tend to happen after their updates such as the profanity filter not working properly. None of these bugs inhibit the game experience. If you need a game to play DCUO is a great one to get your hands on.Edit:While I will still recomend this game, the developers are pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥. They are startting to make big changes though. There will be an update that is a HUGE stat revamp that will change the game as a whole. While this update will not be happening anytime soon, it is good to know the the devolopers are doing something good for this game. As for the membership part, you can only buy it using via credit cards now. If you see daybreak cards at Walmart or any of the stores that sell them, it won't work because they stopped shipping those cards out. You can use those prepaid credit cards if you do not have a legit credit card.

Posted: July 30, 2013
												This is a really fun game.  It kept me entertained for several hours, the missions, side quests, challenges are all fun!  Also I liked how they let you customize your character. You can choose to be a hero or a villian.  I choose villian to have the Joker as my mentor.  Also it's awesome that it's free, but you have to pay for DLC.  The one downside is that when you start out you are just getting into the game and really high level enemies come to kill the low level players.  That really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off but I got used to it.  So if you want to try out the game it's free.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I don't think I've spent more time in any other MMO. I've played Star Wars Galaxies, Lord of the Rings Online, The Old Republic, Dungeons and Dragons Online, Aion: Ascension, Runes of Magic, and a few others and haven't like an MMO as much as I like DCUO. Its extremely cool and satisfying to control every aspect of your hero, like whether they fly or have super-speed, control ice or fire or time itself, and each and every piece of their outfit. The voices are actually well-done in this, featuring Adam Baldwin, Mark Hamill, Wil Wheaton, and Gina Torres, among others. Try this out; I mean, seriously, ITS FREE.

												After about a year of not playing, I decided to try and get back into the game. I noticed that it was no longer run by Station, but now by Daybreak and asked for my Daybreak user ID and information. I thought that maybe I just couldn't remember it so I had my password changed and when that still didn't work, I had my username verified.Now I know that that means that I used all the right information yet it still wasn't working. Couldn't contact customer support either because my account information was being registered as invalid. I enjoy the game, but I'm loath to create a new account because I had some paid content on there. Fun game, but horrible customer support. Can't even play anymore.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												NO I would not reccomend this to anyone..Sure, it's fun to play at start, but gets boring really fast..And if you decide to go away, and when you come back half a year after, you might suddenly have all your characters and data removed, because you didnt read the FORUM, that you had to migrate the account yet another time, middle of the time you were away.. There is no mail to your account saying anything about it, only info about it in the mail is: "you MAY merge your account now".. Support is not helpfull at all, and just dismiss requests with the message: read the forum... When you aks why your data was removed..Patching is done in the afternoon if you live in Europe, so, guess what, no playing after you get home from schoool/work.Oh and information about the patch, often comes out only an hour before they take everything down...Do yourself a favor, and do NOT bother with this one..

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												A pay-to-win game and it wants to rob you blind.1. Newbie-UNFriendly.- Difficult to get situated in, - Mew players are basically lost and SOL.- The game stops holding your hand and telling you where to go very early on.- High level, high aggro mobs hanging out in low level areas, good luck surviving that.2. Free members basically can't do anything. - Your in-game currency is capped ridiculously low... (1500 when you can get millions.)- ...so you can't even get the better items. - Forget endgame unless you subscribe because you have to BUY the Endgame Content. For real money, yes.- This can be circumvented by subscribing for 15 usd a month except--YOU CANNOY SUBSCRIBE VIA STEAM. The game seems really fun and they could make more money by not being so money-hungry, except it's developed by dumbasses.Warframe does it right.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Was a good game, the PVP was great. Servers got hacked but everybody was compensated with Batman style masks etc..  Then for European players like myself, i was moved to ProSeiben (spell) servers. Took 2 weeks to get my characters back. My Batman mask was gone and "there was nothing they could do"  about that. I had to change my log in name to start playing again.All set up again after the server move, i start playing again, i create 16 new characters, i am still a little sore about not getting my batman mask after my personal details were hacked but i continued on. THen i get an email that i am being moved server again. After a 2 hour rigmarole i managed to change server. But not until i change my Username again !!  I change server and everything seems a little quiet. 6 months later i am yet to see a bad guy on the server. So i can no longer play. Time and money invested in this game wasted. Just feel messed about by them at this stage.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This game is fun for about 15 minutes. Based heavily on the gameplay and engine from the Justice League games on console this game offers prettier graphics but very little depth. There really isn't a consistent story to pull a player in. You can choose a mentor which sets you up with a loose storyline to follow but is bisected, quadrasected, basically chopped to bits by other intersecting mini stories. And that's a large part of the problem. There isn't any reason to KEEP playing the game besides leveling up and getting better items. But to what end? To play the same mini stories and complete the same redundant tasks. Don't get me wrong I am not saying the game is all bad. What I am saying is that if DCU was a food it would taste like carboard. Considering the age of the game and the lack of changes and updates made over the YEARS it has existed it's pretty obvious there aren't many plans for improving the game at all. The powers you get to choose from are quite limited and become pretty bland when so many other players have the exact same powers you do. The ability to create a unique hero or villain is extremely limited. I would recommend this game as again a least of the terrible games Steam offers. Be prepared to hit a ceiling unless you want to pay for membership though because this is definitely a money game. And if I am going to spend money on a game it damn sure won't be this one. Play it for free, have a little fun, and get rid of it.

												It's a great concept: create your own superhero while being mentored by all the popular DC comics characters, however the small level cap, the inconsistent chat system, and the difficulty of finding players to raid with makes this a truly disappointing experience. It shows potential and will be fun for the first few hours, but will ultimately let you down.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												After attempting to give this game a go a few times I just felt I was no pushing my identity forward with my own hero, I just felt more like a sidekick to the main heroes and that I didn't feel any connection with the story. The one thing I did like was the way armour worked as you could equip armour then either keep the armour or use anything previously equipped as part of the costume. However the combat seemed very clunky and it's also difficult to chat with the other players in the game.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Alot of Fun but very mixed up when it comes to building a player you want from weapon to certain powers, its all a mess. Many players argue like children when you ask certain questions about the game, plus half of them speak only spanish. You have to Buy your way through the game which basically takes away the fun. Currencies are limited, powers, Player bases. Checking out the furniture was a disappointment, there were no normal Beds or any pieces you'd place in a player base, just junk. The Economy through the "broker" is expensive and rediculous. People are not Friendly or Helpful, Server maintenance lasts hours every 2 or 3 days in between.

												When you start it, it's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. The customization is great, the free roam is really amazing, with fun huge maps. This review is written from memory and I don't know if they changed anything. I HIGHLY SUGGEST YOU START THOUGH, just to get hooked. Note there is DLC and an ingmae currency for some powers and wicked armour but see that's not that important unless you wanna be OP. I was never so invested that I'd visit forums or see what devs are doing (I was younger so I wasn't following updates). tl;dr just play it and see if you like the late game experience. Starts great though!

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												This has been a ton of fun for casual play. In past MMOs I've played, the two biggest pet peeves I've had is lack of character customization and mobility at lower levels of play. As a casual player, I don't usually find myself playing at the higher levels where the cooler-looking gear and mobility options are found in other MMOs, DC Universe Online takes a different approach. Character creation, from the onset, gives you a wealth of starting looks, powers, and tweaks to choose from to make a variety of unique-feeling characters. Medieval barbarian with fire magic? Go for it. Futuristic flying robot with machine pistols? You can do that to. You even have some choices with different idle and movement animations, which helps even more with making your character feel distinct.Character movement is also a blat from the game's start. There are no mounts in this game. Instead, you choose from one of a few movement capabilities  such as Flight, Super Speed, and Acrobatics. All of these make transit between quests as much fun as any other part of the game. I personally love using Acrobatics to scale tall buildings, leap from them, glide across the skies of Gotham, and land with a ground-shattering smash at my quest destination. I've never played an MMO where going from point A to point B was so much fun it itself. Another aspect I enjoyed was the integration of DC comic characters in most of the quests you undertake. I have a passing familiarity with the DC roster from days watching the Justice League/Justice League Unlimted cartoons, so seeing various heroes pop up at the end of a quest for my villain character to immolate and punch in the face provides a lot of entertainment value for me. There's a lot of voice-acting done here, including the iconic performances of Mark Hamil as the Joker and Kevin Conroy as Batman. The game is definitely not perfect. Much of the content is behind paywalls, and Daybreak will not hesitate to remind you of this every step of the way; however, I've been able to experience much of the game without paying a penny. The combat is so-so. There are some cool combos and tricks, but a lot of it revolves around chaining together "stun lock" loops. They're satisfying to pull off at times, but the game comes to a standstill when a swarm of NPCs are doing the same to you all in unison. Overall, I'd recommend this for folks who want a fun casual MMO experience where they can create all sorts of goofy characters and have them run around the world of DC comics.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												I've read alot of reviews claiming that dcuo's free to play model is false advertising but this couldn't be further from the truth.The amount of time it would take you to complete all the free content could range anywhere from 40 hours to hundereds depending on whether or not you go for all the feats or just rush through the content. When dcuo was released it was a $60 release that sold very well, held a strong playerbase for many years and went free to play to offer players a way to experience the game without having to invest to see if they would like it first.but as all free to play games will, dcuo has its ways of genereting a profit to pay it's dev team, this is broken down into episodes you can purchase that act as dlc's. none of these effect the base game. all orignial content as well as the first two dlcs are completely free. may even be more but i have paid to have a membership since the switch to f2p so i can't say exactly how many dlc's are part of the free package.The only valid argument about how bad the f2p model is comes from the fact that they do limit the mount of ingame cash you can carry on your character as a free member. this is annoying but not hindering to progression, since anything you would buy with in game cash is purely cosmetic aside from gear mods which you don't need until you get into the dlc's anyways.Now.......to the review.i've played thousands upon thousands of games in my life time, none of which can hold a candle to dcuo. when i tried to get my fiance to play it she thought it was boring the first few hours. fast forward three years and she's clocked over a thousand hours and wont play anything else.the exact same thing happend to my buddy when i showed it to him, he wasn't sure about it the first couple days, now dcuo is his all time favorite game. also putting in over a thousand hours.For an mmo the combat is fast and fun. the movement is in the vien of games like protoype and infamous where you can fly, freerun, or zip around at lighting speeds like the flash. each power is unique and requires a different mind set while using them, content pacing is good and story development is colorful and fully voice acted from the tutorial to the latest dlc. only reading you have to do is when your choosing your skills/powers.PVP shines in dcuo, though buggy at times it plays more like a arcade fighter then your typical mmo. Where blocking at the right times and following up with a hard hitting combo will reign supreme over following a predetemed skill rotation.character customization is better here then any game i've played. your "styles" are choosen and edited seperately from your gear. so you never have to choose between looking the way you want and being geared with the right equipment. in this case you can have your cake and eat it too. this leads to a ton of inspired characters, leading to many nights that had me and my friends flying around for hours just checking out everyones characters.as far as end game content goes, its never a dull moment. the content will bring you defeat if your not paying attention, but it never means more then respawning and trying the fight over again. with each tier of gear you get drastically stronger and it gives the vibes of something quite similar to reaching that next level of super sayian if you where goku. I stopped playing for about six months due to the fact that update 47♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥a few people off and the player base got a bit smaller, but since my return there are as many people as ever and in a weeks time they are merging the pc and playstation servers with crossplay functionality which will triple the playerbase for those of use that play on pc. this is not an exageration the playstion playerbase is huge.I could go one and on about my love for this game but i'll let this tome of a review and my playtime speak for what I havent already said.would I recommend this game? does a bear $*** in the woods?but don't take my word for it, tho not free in its complete form its free to try, so give it a go.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												I'm going to preface this review by admitting first that it is very difficult for me to get into an MMO in general.  I spent what I feel are too many hours on World of WarCraft only because I had friends who played, but I can't help but feel it just got worse as it became more casual with every new update.  For someone like me to get into an MMO, it has to have a good story that is being played through, and it can't just be repetative if it is not challenging, and the only MMOs I can say I've ever liked are both action MMOs, Star Trek Online and Defiance.  Yes, they can also be repetative, but they are challenging, fast-paced, and require plenty of changes in strategy for different situations, all the while having very engaging stories.  I love the idea of getting immersed in fantasy MMOs too, but as I get older and continue to take on more real-life responsibilities, they are simply too slow-paced, and ironically, the ones I liked the best, like LOTRO and Conan, seem to be the least popular, and I feel as though all of them go quickly to crap as soon as they become free-to-play and pay-to-win.  And lastly, I don't feel as though I should be forced to waste time levelling just because all of the fun things to do in any particular MMO are all 'end-game'.That said, just take my review for what it is, one person's opinion who this game might simply not be for.  For starters, DC Universe does have a tremendous amount of customization options for the creation of one's character.  The problem is that it feels like it pretty much ends there, because no matter what sort of character you create, they all play the same.  You have your melee attack, your ranged attack, and effects that you can add to them, which are also mostly the same between character types.  The action is certainly fast, but highly repetative and not at all challenging.  You'll actually have to try, or have something like a controller malfunction happen, to die.  Like most MMOs, all quests are go here, fetch this/beat up this person/these people, and then go back to turn it in.  Worse, I absolutely hate collectibles.  The slow down the action to search for and all you have to do is find a map online to locate them, and the rewards aren't worth a damn.  The controllers are horrible when climbing if you choose Acrobatics or Speed-type movements; too often you get stuck on any small outcropping of buildings as the directional controls change and your character spazzes out.  And the stories are boring as hell because, as somewhat mentioned before, all story quests invlove going to a place, beating up baddies, beating up the supervillain, rinse, repeat.  And this game has one of the worst PVP systems I'd ever seen.  There is literally no level matching, so you never know going into a PVP match whether your level 12 Character is going up against a level 30 opponent and vice versa.  You'd have to be a pretty big DC fan to be able to keep going after all of this.  The last straw for me was when I discovered that, at times, a free player must wait in a long queue while Members and Premium players login almost immediately.  That is just ridiculous.
